The growth in sales in countries like China makes it possible that apple will break the 75 million sales record. However, it is unlikely due to the reasons stated above.

I tried the following thought experiment. On 26th of October, Tim Cook has indicated that he expected iPhones sales to be higher this quarter than the 2015Q1 (74.47M). “We believe that iPhone will grow in Q1” “Is it revenue? I was making a revenue statement but units are also, yes we expect units to be up as well.” (Tim Cook quotes from conference call transcripts on SeekingAlpha). Tim Cook does not make many of these forward looking statements and he does not strike me as the person to make these type of forecasts lightly.  On the 26th of October, Tim Cook most likely knew the amount of iPhones sold up to 26th October (about 1/3 of the 2016Q1). The question is how many iPhone sold up to that time would him make comfortable expecting overall growth? I asked myself what number I would be comfortable with even if I had more information than I have.  (He will have better data and a clear sales pattern in mind) I would most likely err on the side of caution. Particularly because that was a month after the introduction of the 6S and 6SPlus. If one thinks of a Sales number for October that would make him comfortable, it is easy to get a lowerbound estimate for the full quarter.  My guess would be a lower bound of at least 24M on the 26th. According to my numbers estimated October sales – based on adaption rate data - where only 29% of estimated sales during the full quarter, an estimate of 24M or higher would lead to ultimate sales of 83M or higher.  21.8M would lead to sales of 75M. But if I was in his shoes that would have sounded too low for comfort.

Beside muddling the impact of supplier reports across specific fiscal quarters, the important distinction bewtween "sales" and "units" is lost. I haven't focused on "sales," which as we know is a function of (unit * price). Here's another headline that may cause many to jump to the wrong conclusion(s): "Apple May Miss FYQ1 and Q2 Estimates on Older iPhone Popularity"
http://blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily/2016/01/20/apple-may-miss-fyq1-and-q2-estimates-on-older-iphone-popularity-says-ubs/ The "estimates" at issue in this article are margin estimates, not units sold estimates. I have long said that to meet the December quarterly unit objective, some margin would likely have to be traded away. The author of this article makes the case that the reduced margins (if true) will be a result of product mix. I have suggested that reduced margins are also a natural result of "channel promotions" (pricing discounts, etc.), and looking forward, "channel maintenance" expenses. The critical issue, beside of course the underlying end-user demand, is the lead time required for Apple to go from initial order to finished unit ready-for-sale to delivered unit. The rumblings of weak supplier news first bubbled up, as I recall, in early December. If the Apple pipeline is less than 30 days, then we should be concerned. I've always assumed it was at least thirty days, and that, no matter what, Apple would be certain to have whatever inventory was required to make the quarterly unit number, if demand should materialize, assembled and ready-to-go. We have some evidence, I believe, that Apple took these ready-to-go units and in fact delivered them into the channel; presumably at a quantity sufficient to exceed the unit number projection. We may understand the mechanics broadly, but the details and the timing are proprietary to Apple. While in a few days we'll know, in the meantime I expect a number of "plausibly true, but only partially relevant to our question" stories to appear.

Will Apple Sell More than 75M iPhones in the December Quarter?

1.	Rate of growth decelerating. Total unit volume growth in 2014 v 2013 was 12.6% compared to 2011 v 2010 growth of 80.8%.  
2.	Largest market is China, China is decelerating based on the market action of the Chinese stock market. 
3.	Q1 has become, since 2012 the largest quarter of the year representing more than 30% of annual volume and Q4 has since 2012 has represented approximately 22 – 23% of annual unit volume. If this trend continues the volume estimate for Q4 would be approximately 52M units.
4.	The iPhone 6 was released in September of 2014 which lead to a significant increase in volume in the subsequent quarters, in fact Q1 2015 is the largest volume quarter ever recorded. To replicate that volume in the same year would require an additional 75M new iPhone users rather than the usual replacement cycle which would have occurred in or about Q1 2015. 
5.	The 6S released in September 2015 will probably also lead to a significant increase in volume however to reach 75M units would be a 190% increase in unit volume over the same quarter in 2014 and a 157% increase over Q3 2015 both of which are increases far greater than in any previous quarter.

I'm still in awe of Gordonei's prediction of 10 Nov. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/39464 and can't praise it enough. Still, as a "seat of the pants" forecaster, I'm less optimistic. Apple is Apple, so I'm staying in the" more likely than not range" but I think two factors may be significant when comparing this year's growth with last year
1) Though 13 million phones were sold in the first three days, the first two days' sales were included in Apple's fourth quarter, unlike last year. If that's the case, the 48.05 million phones sold in 4Q15 should be reduced by 8-9 million ie. two thirds of 13 million, when comparing growth with 4Q14.
2) China was not among the markets in the first weekend for the 6 last year, but the 6s and Plus were sold in China from the start this year. It seems something like 3-4 million of these were sold in China on the first weekend this year, so these numbers should also be taken out from the 48.05 figure for a comparison with the previous year. Taking the two above, a conservative "apple to apple" (sorry but can't resist) comparison should have 4Q15 as no more than 40 million compared to the 39.27 of 4Q14.   Gordonei's second approach, applying the geometric mean of the previous several years growth, would lead to a result less than 75 million if the figure of 48.02 was replaced by about 43 or less. As suggested by the two points above, this substitution seems quite reasonable to me. I'm not competent to review Gordonei's first approach, the "German Tank" model, except that small differences in some of the ratios could change the result significantly since the "Country Muliplier" is fairly large at 27.745. If this was 25 then the total calculated would be under 75 million again i.e. if UK's share was 4.0% instead of the calculated 3.6%. This number is derived from (144*10^7/376*10^5)*(0.2/0.3) so will be quite sensitive to relatively small changes in the component numbers.

It will be close but I think they will make it. Professional analysts predict just above 75 mln and the indies higher. Total average 78 mln. (over the years analyst prediction in aggregate seem to have become a bit more reliable).
- I don't believe the 10% slash story with some suppliers. In the past these stories have always proven not to have any relation with actual sales.
- The law of large numbers argument is only put forward by people who do not seem to understand what the law of large numbers actually is about. 
- There may be some cannibalism from the new products (Apple Watch, Apple TV, iPad Pro) but that will be off-set by a halo effect of new Apple users (increasing market share in PC's etc).
- The Chinese market is becoming increasingly important in sales and particularly US based investors and analysts seem to have difficulty to understand its sheer size and potential and the love Chinese Apple users seem to feel for their iPhones). 
- The new annual upgrading program seems hugely popular which may help increase the US numbers
- The iPhone 6S has become available in many more countries and much faster than with previous releases
- Economies are recovering a bit allowing more consumers to treat themselves after the tougher years
- Apple's new strategy in India might also start to take off. 
- Only twenty percent of current iPhone owners have upgraded and so there is a large potential there for new phones as iPhone users hardly switch.

I originally wasn't going to bother with this question, but I saw this article recently (http://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog/the-german-tank-problem.html) on Hacker News, and it got me thinking...  Assuming that most of the new phones sold would be the new ones, i.e. iPhone 6S and iPhone 6S Pluses, I used serial numbers off eBay in the UK (from product photos) to work out how many phones there were approximately in the country. I then found the worldwide number of 6Ss, using the market share of Apple in the UK relative to the world and the smartphone market size of the UK, relative to the world. Then, I used the released sales figures for Q4 2015 to account for those that were sold in that quarter. Finally, I used a linear projection to work out, based upon the number of phones sold so far in this quarter, the total for Q1 2016, which I project to be 82.4 million phones. This of course ignores Christmas, which I might have to revisit in the future. Another, less interesting way (in my opinion i.e. no less valid), is to look at what happens to sales in the quarter after Apple releases a new phone internationally (i.e. from the iPhone 3GS onwards). In more recent years this has always neatly been at the end of the 4th quarter (i.e. the one before December), but in previous years this has been more towards the beginning of a quarter. Looking at the geometric mean of the factor difference between the quarter where most of the new sales occurs and previous one, there is projected to be 82.9 million phones sold in Q1 2016. Both methods are pretty conclusively above 75 million, although the standard deviation on the Bayesian method is considerable - I need to crunch the stats properly to quantify it, but it looks to be roughly a 10% chance it'll be below 75M. Adjusting for additional information from Apple's FY15Q4 briefing: iPhone sales in Q4 increased by 22% YoY (1% QoQ), reaching 48m units. 
In terms of YoY growth this is very close to the average growth over the last couple of years, while it is one of the lowest QoQ growth figures. Historically, Q1s have always been high growth quarters, profiting from increased consumer expenditure over the holidays. In recent years we have seen QoQ growth figures ranging from 51% to 90%. Assuming in-line growth figures of ~70%, we would see 82m units sold in FY16Q1. It is also imperative to note that we would need to see QoQ growth at the bottom of the range at <56% to come in at less than 75m units sold.
For this model I will assume QoQ growth of 60%, putting unit sales at 77m. Examining YoY growth figures for recent quarters we see a general downwards trend with the highest figure from FY15Q1 at 46% YoY growth and FY15Q4 at the bottom of the range with 22%. Assuming the trend continues, we will see roughly 17% YoY growth in FY16Q1. I will assume a more conservative 15%, which would see unit sales of 86m. In order to follow the slowing YoY growth trend, I have decided to weight expected YoY growth at 60%, while using the remaining 40% to account for the seasonal Q1 "pop" in sales figures. Hence, using unit sales implied by the YoY growth trend as a baseline (86m units) and adjusting downwards as we incorporate a conservative Q1 pop (77m), my estimate would put FY16Q1 iPhone unit sales at about 82m, with significant upside potential. As even the most conservative component implies more than 75m units shipped, I adjust my forecast upwards to 90%.

Upside risks: Reversal of YoY growth trend, bigger than expected Q1 pop, positive demand drivers (Rose Gold, Apple Upgrade Program, Force Touch), positive demand shocks (higher consumer spending, lower than expected economic slowdown in key markets) Downside risks: Change in seasonal consumption pattern (absorption of Q1 sales into Q4), negative economic shocks (slowdown in key markets), stronger than expected YoY growth slowdown Sources:

I mean, if they were not expecting at least a 1% increase (750,000 units), you'd think he would have avoided using the word "grow," and instead have said something more like "on pace." +5 [Edit: A review of the conference call transcript reveals that Tim Cook, CEO, also explicitly provides positive guidance: "We believe that iPhone will grow in Q1." The problem with a financial officer delivering an operational estimate is that the only mechanism they personally have to control the outcome is to manipulate the *reporting* of the results. On the other hand, when an operating officer delivers an estimate, there is at least the assurance that they are in a position to manipulate the *actual performance* of the result. Obviously this heuristic does not apply when the operation under consideration is itself a financial operation (e.g., hedging).]

New forecast based on learning Apple's fiscal calendar does not coincide with the calendar year.  Overall, Apple's iPhone sales growth is an exponential function, and these have a habit of surprising to the upside as humans are more inclined to think linearly; it's far more intuitive. I have some concerns with slowing demand in many large consumer nations; however, it appears, China's cell-phone market is far from being saturated and recent demand for the iphone has been nearly insatiable. I was initially drawn into the doubt that Apple would not reach the 75m mark, but found a few issues with the Pacific Crest analysis. Firstly, it's just one analysis of the situation from a firm with a track record that I can't find out. The analysis also seems to be focused on the 6S' sales, and reading over my previous forecast, I read how with the 6 now being $100 cheaper, sales growth won't just come from the 6S. 
More importantly with the analysis, there wasn't as much detail as I'd have liked. Assuming that the excerpts which have been published in articles like this (http://www.businessinsider.com.au/iphone-6s-sales-disappointing-pacific-crest-2015-10), which have been mentioned by quite a few others before me, are all that he's said on this topic and is all the detail that he goes into, then it has to be questioned what Apple's initial "component orders" or "expectations" were. It's all relative; so if Apple's initial expectations and component orders were for iPhone sales of say 80m, then below expectations or "disappointing sales" might not mean sales will fall below 75m. His sources might have been similarly vague about describing sales. How does he calculate an estimate of 67m units?
In terms of what he says about fewer stores selling out of iPhones, as I recall, last year's iPhone release had supply issues considering demand beat expectations (quick search gives 71.5m) and also issues with manufacturing the 6 Plus' larger screen.
On the final point, that “almost all carriers surveyed indicated that iPhone 6s sales were down y/y, compared to the iPhone 6.”, I'm assuming he's referring to US carriers. Now couldn't it be possible that people just aren't buying from carriers and are waiting for the sim-free (unlocked) iPhone? (which apparently just started production http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/10/08/apple-starts-sales-of-sim-free-iphone-6s-6s-plus-handsets)
This article goes over some of the points raised here and in my previous forecast: http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2015/10/12/the-iphone-sales-slump-doomsayers-are-forgetting-t.aspx
Overall, its probably still a bit early to say that the 75m mark won't be reached since many countries haven't even started selling iPhones yet, but just in case all my assumptions are wrong, there's a decrease in my forecast.
